summary: "The greatest trick the devil ever pulled was convincing the world he didn't exist," says con man Kint (Kevin Spacey), drawing a comparison to the most enigmatic criminal of all time, Keyser Soze. Kint attempts to convince the feds that the mythic crime lord not only exists, but is also responsible for drawing Kint and his four partners into a multi-million dollar heist that ended with an explosion in San Pedro Harbor - leaving few survivors.

reviews.content: I know a lot of fans of this film. I found it to be somewhat of a convoluted mess.

The Usual Suspects' simple yet clever script is elevated by the brilliant performances of its talented cast. Kevin Spacey shines in this mystery thriller and it's not even on par with his best work. Although the pacing faltered after the second act, the plot twist ending more than made up for it.

You have to watch it twice -- not just once and not more than three times.
Twice. That's all.

One of the best surprise endings ever

This movie is spectacularly performed by the actors, and the writing is very fine-tuned. It features surprises, action, and suspense that stays under-played rather than over-developed. I wouldn't let anyone ruin the ending for you, so be careful who you ask about this movie. It isn't the best thing in the universe, but if you don't know how it ends, it's fun. When I was younger this was my favorite movie of all time. It has aged pretty well, and the acting is outstanding from everyone involved in the project. The surprises are throughout the movie, making it fun to watch. Del Toro's performance especially, the scene where he pisses on the fire, and the ending make this a must-see.

IMHO the greatest film of all time. Some say Shawshank Redemption. Either way it is outstanding. Huge cast of outstanding actors, edge of seat stuff, a film you can watch numerous times. An opportunity to see the legend Pete Postlethwaite.  10/10

The greatest trick the Devil ever pulled was convincing the world he didn't exist. 'The Usual Suspects' grows around a fascinating theme, with a mind-blowing plot twist to uncover, which is hinted at all throughout the movie. The way tension is built up at the end makes the plot end flawless. Superb acting and the atmosphere was great overall. 10/10
Great movie, great twist.
I suspect something unusual - Light 8/10

This is a movie that you can only appreciate as a classic, if you watch it to the end. You stop half way, its just a caper movie, but you watch it to the end, and you know you had a magnificent experience
It is a shocking story that defies expectations and defies cinema conventions. Nothing can compare to the immense impact of the last act.
Damn enthralling and mind-boggling, The Usual Suspects is perfectly shot, edited, written and acted with a tense athmosphere giving weight to its wonderfully crafted, smart and twisty plot.
What a awesome masterpiece 10/10
A fantastic crime story
If you like crime mysteries that keep you guessing until the end, this is perhaps the most notorious movie for setting up a brilliantly satisfying plot-twist that you'll ever see.
Great actors, great acting and a twist at the end.

As an avid cinephile, who watches a lot of films to help me to be distracted from the pressures of everyday life, old and new and of all genres (have never had a bias against any genre and never love older films and dismiss new films, or vice versa), 'The Usual Suspects' was one of the finest films personally seen in a while.

Other films to have that effect on me (and garnered 10/10 ratings, a rare rating for me these days) are 'LA Confidential', 'Amores Perros', Orson Welles' version of 'The Trial', 'City of God' and 'The Song of Bernadette', though some films came close as well as re-watches of favourites like 'Se7en', 'Much Ado About Nothing' (1993) and 'The Remains of the Day'.

Simply put, 'The Usual Suspects' is a magnificent film all round that deserves to be re-watched over and over again, one of the few films seen recently to not find any fault with it. Fully deserving of its reputation as one of the best modern, and perhaps overall, films ever made. Not everybody is going to disagree and that is fine.

'The Usual Suspects' is slickly and audaciously made, filmed with a lot of style and is atmospherically directed. It is also hauntingly scored. It is intricately and intelligently written by Christopher McQuarrie, some of the best screen-writing he ever did. It is beautifully and deftly directed by Bryan Singer. If remembered correctly, neither McQuarrie or Singer were well known at the time and it was 'The Usual Suspects' that put them on the map.

Film is famous for the iconic line-up scene, the noticeboard that haunts everybody forever and its killer twist, one for the ages and not one to forget in the long one. Twists have wildly varied in film, there are some ingenious ones but also some naff ones, 'The Usual Suspects' is one of the ingenious ones. 'The Usual Suspects' as said before doesn't just have its twist going for it. The flashback-packed story is similarly intricate and never feels muddled or convoluted.

It has some of the finest ensemble acting there has ever been. This is especially true for a mesmerising Kevin Spacey in one of the most deserved Oscar Wins that year. Spacey is just one of the all round brilliant performances. Pete Postelthwaite, an always dependable actor who is still very much missed, is suitably mysterious, and Dan Hedaya and Chazz Palminteri make their mark as the confused cops. Steven Baldwin doesn't have a particularly challenging role but has never been better, Gabriel Byrne is also solid.

Overall, magnificent film in every sense. Recommended with no hesitation. 10/10 Bethany Cox

Wow, what's not to like in Usual Suspects?  Great storyline, and great plot twists, and turns.  The movie is beautifully shot and the writing and acting are great.  I'm a Kevin Spacey fan, and I have to say this is one of his best, and most memorable, roles.
One of my favorite movies of all time.... amazing.

Top score for this crime drama. Love this movie. The twists and suspense were just amazing. And the momentary slashes of humor were memorable even to this day I still.remember the interrogation scenes and the funny and clever comebacks. Cheers

This is a sometimes gripping, mysterious watch with a great cast. The plot develops reasonably slowly but it features some good action scenes and kept me guessing. I liked Pete Postlethwaite's asian accent (he plays a character called Kobayashi). 

It has a bit of a film noir feel to it, in that its gritty, urban and a little bit spooky, with some mildly unsettling music played subtly in the background to remind the viewer that anything could happen at a seconds notice.

It is dark and bizarre but its definitely a good watch and the pace hots up towards the end. This is a film I'd recommend.

Despite some of the people involved in this project, it still holds up as a tense crime thriller with one of the best endings.

A simple character reveal that reshapes the entire film on a second viewing.
Expertly shot, written, and acted. Not flashy. But subtle and engaging, with some incredible twists. One of Spacey's best. Recommended.

In many ways, Brian Singer's The Usual Suspects feels a lot like Tarantino's Reservoir Dogs – a caper gone horribly wrong, a cast of interesting and well-developed criminals, loads of snappy dialogue, and bursts of graphic violence, among other things.  Without giving away too much for the uninitiated, the action all centers around the existence (or myth) of the mysterious Keyser Soze, who one character summarizes by saying ‘I believe in God and the only thing that scares me is Keyser Soze.'  The plot is labyrinthine but not impossible to follow, the cast is excellent, much of the dialogue is highly quotable, and the twist in the final scene is remarkable.  Unlike so many movies with twist endings, The Usual Suspects may actually be more engaging with additional viewings once you're aware of the story behind the Soze mystery.

The film was entreteined, the performances were good, and the direction and cinematography were also fine. The problem is the story: It's really well-constructed, but it's not that hard to figure out how the film will end.
Quite good. Nice twist in the end. DelToro is nice.
The Usual Suspects weirdly shot timeline was unnecessarily confusing and could've easily been avoided. Otherwise it was interesting to watch and made me interested to see how everything played out.

Great flick, good action; Fun characters; Believable story; Amazing twist, at the end -
THEN it gets better; Albeit I saw it coming, it was a thouroughly great ride.
MUST WATCH for any American crime drama/mystery fans

1995 knew many hits, not all expected, and The Usual Suspects was one of them. This movie was directed by Bryan Singer before he blew the minds of many comic book fans with a couple amazing X-Men-movies. Starring an impressive cast consisting of Benicio Del Toro, Gabriel Byrne, Kevin Spacey and Stephen Baldwin, this movie had a lot going for it. It made some pretty big waves after its release and is now old enough to be considered a classic.

A massive gunfight results in a veritable bloodbath and fire in the Los Angeles Harbor, causing an incredible loss of life. Verbal Kint, a professional con-man and full-time cripple, seems to be one of the only survivors of this disaster. He is apprehended and tells the story of the events leading up this debacle. Here, he eventually pins the blame on Keyser Söze, a psychopathic and rutless kingpin, believed to be more of a mythical boogieman than an actual person.

What makes this movie stand out- at least for me- is the entire mystery surrounding the character of Keyser Söze. He is as imposing and threating, as he ethereal. This character throws a long shadow over the story that looms just beyond the limits of the screen. This makes the entertaining characters and heists they're pulling of even more interesting, as they are slowly being pulled into a maelstrom that could mean the end of them. Each role is masterfully played, as both Kevin Spacey and Gabriel Byrne truly shine in their respective personas. 
While the movie has aged well in a narrative sense, its wrinkles are showing in its more simplistic sense of cinematography. Conversations are simple back-and-forths, establishing shots are pans. 'Suspects' could have used a bit more of a dynamic style to fit the ever-moving pace of the story.
It has some slower beats, that are mostly necessary for the pacing anyhow. 

I had a good time with this movie, and anyone that hasn't seen it can get my recommendation for it. Despite its age, I refuse to give away any spoilers, as its ending is iconic to say the least. 
'The Usual Suspects' receives an 8.5/10.
Awesome movie, don't look anything up about it before watching.  I usually don't like mob/cop dramas/heist movies, but this one is worth watching.
A classic who-done-it film that I waited to long to watch.
This is not what I expected! This definitly was more then I expected. This is what 90's movies was and what is missed. The cinamatography, story and execution were done beautifully.

I went into watching this movie knowing only two things about it: I knew it was a project that launched Kevin Spacey's career (and say what you will about him as a human being, but he did a damn good job acting in this movie), and that there's a mind-blowing twist at the end that is pretty much the dictionary definition of a twist ending. And I will say, it's very difficult to discuss the film at any length without giving away the ending. The script is good, the visuals are fantastic at points (that shot of the shattering coffee mug will live rent-free in my head for quite some time), and the acting is pretty spot on. You can tell these boys had a fun time making this movie. I will say though—some gripes that I'm not faulting the movie itself for, since it was made in 1995—it's difficult in the year 2022 to watch a movie with so much unchecked casual homophobia, and it's genuinely a little hard to differentiate five individual main characters when they are all white men.

All told, though, this movie is good. As a screenwriter myself, I'm definitely taking notes on how to craft a satisfying ending that ties just enough up to be satisfying and still leaves you with a lot of questions. The last 15 minutes of the film alone are worth the price of admission. I'll be curious to watch it a second time knowing the ending and see what I pick up on that I didn't on this first time through.
I don't regret not having finished watching it. it's so bad. 1/10

Well written, with an excellent ending twist. The plot was memorable and thought out, the characters were believable and varied, the cast was appropriate, the acting was solid, and there was enough enjoyable action. However, the writing was arguably a bit muddled/confusing at times, the pacing wasn't perfect, and the lighting could have been better. The cinematography, visual effects, sets/props/costumes, and soundtrack were all reasonable but not extraordinary.

The story can be a bit to take in at certain points but Spacey is kind of a Heath Ledger Joker type of villain for the 90s. He makes the movie what it is, being a good film!

No exaggeration. As others have pointed out, once we get to the surprise ending, the reaction is...hey, what did we just see for the past two hours? I was at a youth hostel in Philadelphia years ago and they showed different movies in the evening including this one. I ended up watching it because at evening in Philadelphia, everything except nightclubs close up. Just as well I didn't pay for it, because while the movie was at first exciting, it then became too confusing and in the end, when we expect the "cripple's" confession to tie everything together and reveal who Keyser Soze was, well...

So we see things in the police office to suggest that the "cripple" had been making up his whole story, that the "cripple" really wasn't, and so on until we get the point that the past two hours were what really didn't happen. And we never find out what really is the truth after all. All this time spent on a false story? This wasn't a surprise ending, this was a gyp!

A fascinating blend of excellent writing, beautiful direction and an ensemble cast playing off of each other perfectly. The story flows effortlessly from one scene to another with pinpoint precision in a film which has aged like a fine wine over the last 25 years. 9/10

One of the greatest movies of all time. So many great lines, and such a great movie all around. Whenever we are looking for a movie to watch with someone who hasn't seen it we suggest this one. Such a great flick.

While this does have to be one of the most overrated movies of all time with its position in the top 50 of IMDb & similar lists, there were a few things prior to the fantastic ending that kept the movie from being really terrible. While my wife did fall asleep watching it and I got a bit droopy-eyed around the middle, I really liked the Redfoot character, thought Palminteri nearly eclipsed Spacey's performance with his aggression and Spacey's narration was top notch. Best of all for me, and really what kept me awake through the uninteresting second act was the film score, which earned no awards recognition but to me was a near-masterpiece! It had my favorite elements of the best film scores I'd previously heard like Jerry Goldsmith's close mimicking of the action and tone of each scene and John Williams's grand scale and near-intrusive volume, exactly the way I like it. He kept to the deeper notes in all the right places and limited the fluttery keys that I'm not as big a fan of. The music during the plot twist of Spacey's other 1995 movie, Se7en, was better at heightening emotion and suspense, but leading up to the finale this score absolutely hit the spot. Given that the twist ending was perfectly done I'm left with a very uneven movie but with key ingredients that were done so well that I can't possibly give a low rating to the finished product. Woohoo!
Great as everyone else has said, but you can only watch it once!
Sometimes a little thick. But largely the twists are satisfying, though often predictable. The performances serve.

With all the focus on its beautifully-realized twist ending it's easy to overlook that this low budget crime caper is engrossing from start to finish and holds up extremely well to the multiple re-watchings that its concept demands.  The cast is perfect, the direction and cinematography belong in a much more expensive movie, and the diabolical complexity of the plot only becomes denser the more you try to unravel it.

Though most could argue that spending 108 minutes of your day watching 'The Usual Suspects' is worth it for the closing alone, it remains a mediocre picture.

I'm not sure why everyone likes this movie so much. I mean, it was fine, but the plot was overly complex and the story was told in a pretty confusing way. There's no character development; in fact, there are hardly any characters. All of the characters have the exact same type of dialogue (who knows that many people that say "cocksucker"?) with barely any distinguishing features. The actors play the five least believable criminals I've ever seen. I think there is one woman in the entire movie and she gets maybe two minutes of screen time.

I guess the twists are interesting enough, but because the movie doesn't give me any reason to care about the characters, it loses any tension it might have had. I'm glad I know what all the fuss is about but I'm not gonna be watching this one again any time soon.

Very disappointing. The movie was full of plot holes and isolated incidents, which made the storyline hard to follow. Multiple characters were introduced throughout the movie to manipulate and confuse the viewer, without advancing the story. There was almost no character development, aside from one, which was used to manipulate the empathetic viewer into a "shock" ending. Despite the predictable ending, gratuitous violence and non existent storyline, the film is beautifully shot. If you appreciate cinematography, watch this movie; if not, just don't.

The Usual Suspects is excellently made and has some great turns. Christopher McQuarrie yet again proves he can write a competent script with many twists and turns, he even misleads the audience. A plot with so many twists and turns you may think that youâ(TM)re riding a roller coaster.  American crooks, Hungarian mobsters, police on two coasts, this story is hard to decipher, but it is an interesting trip down gangster way.

Strengths: You can't discuss this movie without talking about the big twist ending. If you haven't seen it yet, I'd give a spoiler alert but the movie is over two decades old. Get on it. There's a reason it's one of the best in cinema history. Kevin Spacey (Roger "Verbal" Kint) gives one of the best performances of his career. You get shocked when the revelation comes at the end, but also are able to look back and see that it makes sense. The mystery around the film is well executed. You can tell that Verbal's story sounds fishy, so you're left wondering what the truth really is. Most of the other cast members also bring their best. Stephen Baldwin (Michael McManus), Gabriel Byrne (Dean Keaton), and Kevin Pollack (Todd Hockner) all do well. Benicio Del Toro (Fred Fenster) was a delightful addition. The way he talked throughout the film makes him memorable. The script is great and this might be the best work of Bryan Singer's career.

Weaknesses: The criminals are mostly great characters. The cops aren't. They come across as very one note and generic, while getting next to nothing in terms of development. I know they aren't the most important piece of the film, but giving them something to work with would've helped things. The pacing of the movie could use some tightening. 

Overall: An absolute classic. It's filled with great, interesting characters and a wild tale that will leave you on the edge of your seat. The twists and turns throughout and especially at the end are the stuff of legend. Phenomenal.

'The Usual Suspects' is that slow burner that at a first glance is a slow and almost boring film -- but that after a while expands into this cleverly written thriller that takes unexpected turns. It's a story of much complexity with a lot of dialogue. This, in combination with the big lack of character depth might seem like a big flaw, but the 3rd act explains a lot of this and it does weigh more than the film's cons -- for some people. I loved the ending but found most of the 1st and 2nd act slow and uneventful. The third act made the whole flick superbly better, mostly thanks to the film's mysterious antagonist, the powerful direction by Bryan Singer and Kevin Spacey's performance as the character 'Verbal'. It's one great and dramatic thriller, but that might be a bit too slow for my taste.

Clever film about a group of US criminals from 1995.
I say clever in that the screenplay is so good.
If you have the opportunity I would recommend a repeat viewing a day or two after.
I did and you spot so many little details and twists that after a sole viewing you might miss.
The premise is quite simple really. A group of 'suspects' are arrested by the New York Police Department on pretty dubious information regarding a stolen truck and end up in the notorious identity parade.
Back in a holding cell the group of 5 hatch a plan for further criminal activity to get one over the NYPD.
All the story is told from the interrogation of one of the suspects Roger 'Verbal' Kint (Kevin Spacey).
The identity of a mysterious boss Keyser Söse becomes a main plot thread throughout. 
The cast includes Spacey, Gabriel Byrne, Stephen Baldwin and a young Benicio Del Toro.
The film oozes quality and was deserving of its box office success back in 1995.

I think there's something to be said about movies that can create an experience, but only based on certain conditions. For instance, I have told friends who didn't see Gravity in theaters not to waste their time on it. The experience of Gravity is one of a kind but almost entirely dependent on a huge screen (with 3-D if possible) to fully appreciate. Similarly, I believe that the full experience of The Usual Suspects only comes when you are able to see it unspoiled. Sadly, I knew the spoiler 20 years ago before even thinking of going to see the film. So, the question is, how does it hold up for someone who sees it for the first time with full knowledge of the conclusion? I thought it was a decent film, with some good plot twists that I didn't mind knowing in advance. This allowed me to look under the hood a little and see how they made the story work in order to blow the minds of audiences everywhere. I had some issues with the casting, because this group of crooks feel more like the light-hearted team from an Ocean's film than the dangerous group of killers in a drama like The Usual Suspects, but the 3 leads (Spacey, Byrne, and Palminteri) were all spectacular. The plot is kind of confusing at first because there are a lot of time jumps and sudden cuts from one location to another, but eventually it all smooths out and becomes easy to follow. My biggest issue with the film is also a big spoiler, so be warned.

*SPOILERS START*  Because it is all told from the viewpoint of an unreliable narrator, we never get to find out exactly what happened. It makes for a big revelation at the end of the film, so I'm sure audiences walked out of the theater stunned without caring about that part. However, when you know the conclusion, it makes the entire film feel like a cheat because everything or nothing we saw could have happened and we don't have any idea.  *SPOILERS END*  Despite my complaints, I think The Usual Suspects is a solid script, that accomplished what it set out to do brilliantly. It will never be a favorite for me because I didn't get the full experience, but I can see why others hold it aloft as one of the greats. I'll just say this, if you like a good crime mystery film and you have no idea who or what Keyser Soze is, then you owe it to yourself to check out this movie because you might still be able to have the experience I was robbed of 20 years ago.

The Usual Suspects stars a band of five misfits who are tasked with pulling off a suicide missions of sorts in order to pull of one last journey to right the many wrongs they have committed in the past. The film opens in San Pedro California the night before where Dean Keaton one of our main characters is shot in cold blood on a boat in the harbor. The plot centers around McManus, Todd, Dean, Verbal Kint and Fenster as they collude to commit heist and crimes of assorted sorts. A mysterious man known simply as Mr. Soze is the mastermind behind an intricate plan to control the crime syndicates around the city of NY. To many he is only a myth, and a legendary tale but to others he is as real as it gets. After they all are arrested in NYC 6 weeks prior to current events they are all questioned to vet and see if they are the right men for the job. Based on their abilities to hijack cars and guns they are pre-picked to complete the operations. In the meantime the NYPD interrogates them to see if they can get information on one of the fugitives Keaton who is facing several indictments. However, as the movie transpires the story thread is not what it seems and we are led down a complicated and at times convoluted plan to shake the cops and carry out a sinister plan. The mission that is being analyzed throughout is the event that led to the death of 27 men for $91 million men and only the survival of one known as Verbal Kint. He was the brains behind the operations and an Agent Kujan is tasked to crack the case. With immunity offered to Kint the different operations that led to the smuggle of ammo out of South America and the heist against Saul for his cash and jewels is never quite pinned. After they meet the lawyer Mr. Kobayashi later in the film they are set on paying their debts back to Mr. Kyzer Soze who has entire files on their criminal pasts. One interesting foreshadow occurs when the lawyers states, "one cannot be betrayed if you know no people." Later when we figure out that Kint is Mr. Soze after attempting to fool the detective and blackmailing his partners this statement makes more sense. Also Kint states, "The greatest trick that the devil ever pulled was convincing the world he didn't exist." What is truly fascinating is this allusions leads us to figure out that Kint is that devil and has been the mastermind behind the whole charade throughout the film. Kint makes everything up and he is a conman in every sense of the word. As a cripple he is able to blackmail, threaten and deceive others who would never expect it. The resolution is a huge shock and makes the convoluted plot payoff as it was very well done. The social commentary of the film seems to point at corruption with the corporate system as well as the police force as Kujan undertakes some dastardly techniques to intimidate and get information from Kint. However, the film's story is original and brilliant in handling each twist and turn. Although this film covers the hunting group of companions archetype since they all are in on the crimes I think that it doesn't quite fit as Kint is manipulated the system the whole time. I think it would be better as man v. monster as the other men are just doing a job but Kint has more insidious plans.

There are disappointing moments within a film critic's lifetime during which they realize that a specific review won't have much influence on the people interested in, or in love with, a film.  Granted, I've never expected to change someone's opinion - more important to me is the art of the recommendation, where a previously clouded masterpiece is able to briefly become new again.  
	So movies like 1995's "The Usual Suspects" are disheartening.  So legendary is it for its shadowy pulp cool and stellar twist ending that most audiences figure it to be a companion piece to the "Pulp Fictions" and "Léon: The Professionals" of the era.  But as long as a plot twist defines the success of a movie and is rather predictable, then my reverence can't be bought.  
	I can see its appeal - audiences tend to like having a plot pulled out like a rug from under their feet so they can feel the effects of a mind explosion - but I, more than once, found myself underwhelmed, confused, or, worst of all, not much interested in what it had to provide.  The storyline, so richly complicated and defined by its characters, builds and builds to an ending that feels like a copout.  
	What is it about "The Usual Suspects" that bothers me so much? Is it its excessive amount of characters, the way it feverishly convolutes its story, the way it never really sells the premise it eventually tries to slip us wholesale? I'm not so sure; it's a lethal cocktail of technical and performative mastery combined with potential that always lets itself be known but never materializes, with audience piano playing that sometimes impresses, but, more or less, hits a lot of wrong notes.
	It begins with promise.  A catastrophic explosion shakes a San Pedro ship, leaving 27 men dead, $91 million of cocaine gone, and two survivors battling the aftermath.  One of them is horribly burned, hardly able to aid investigators; the other, Roger "Verbal" Kint (Kevin Spacey), a talkative cripple, is relatively unscathed, his tendency to never sit quietly heightened by his paranoia.  Two detectives with persona agendas, Jack Baer (Giancarlo Esposito) and Dave Kujan (Chazz Palminteri), stalk the scene.
	Most of the story is presented through the recollections of Verbal, whose testimony begins five days previously and involves four criminals, including dirty cop Dean Keaton (Gabriel Byrne), suave thief Michael McManus (Stephen Baldwin), the linguistically challenged Fred Fenster (Benicio Del Toro), and hijacker Todd Hockney (Kevin Pollack).  The quintet becomes acquainted when they are brought in as suspects for a recent gun shipment robbery; none are guilty, all annoyed at their detaining.  When McManus makes them a proposition that includes intercepting the transport of a police-escorted smuggler, swiping his noteworthy loot in the process, support is universal.
	The job is completed without a bead of sweat in sight, leading to the group characterizing their chemistry as something finer than most.  More jobs with bigger payoffs sounds much more rewarding.  They continue on a path of a criminality but are slowed when legendary (and always unseen) Hungarian crime lord Keyser Söze enters the scene with a job that holds great financial reward but also great mortal risk - if unsuccessful, mass murder will ensue.
	This assignment, of course, leads to the present day situation, where Verbal is a sole survivor and the police become heavyweights of baffled psyches.  Verbal's truths never seem as cemented as we would like them to be (he's a pathological liar and a victim of an unforgiving society), making for mangled narration that puzzles investigators just as much as it puzzles us.
	The story is a brand of confusing that rarely works in the movies, the kind where labyrinthine storytelling tactics become too much; we find ourselves furrowing our brow, unsuccessfully trying to recount past details to land somewhere between enjoyability and comprehensibility.  To regally follow exactly what's going on is a feat I applaud anyone for mastering.  The lauded plot twist (is it that great, though?) is underwhelming because we never cared too much about what was going on anyway.
	So while the performances are good and Singer's direction has moments of artful mastery, "The Usual Suspects" doesn't satisfy because we expect it to be so much more than it actually is - it promises to be a twisty story of murder and deceit that ends with an exclamation mark, but conversely proves itself as hysteria with an ellipsis at its tail.  But I wouldn't listen to me here; everyone loves "The Usual Suspects" so much that I currently act as the hater that stands on the sidelines cheering for the wrong team, alone.  It's all a matter of taste.

Knowing the plot of this movie would probably be convoluted, I made a real effort to pay attention to everything. My mind has wandered before in complex stories like this; sometimes, paying more attention would've only slightly elevated a needlessly complicated story (True Detective season 2), but sometimes, paying more attention would've made me appreciate the story more (LA Confidential or Chinatown). So I was determined to make complexity a non-issue when it came to my enjoyment of this movie.

I pretty much loved most of this movie. The directing is stylish and fun, and though much of the movie is talky, it didn't feel low on incident/action like some pre-2000s crime movies can. The dialogue is great, and I was interested in all the characters and the dynamics between the group. It reminded me of Reservoir Dogs, with all these guys and their different criminal histories and their different attitudes towards crime and murder all coming together to make some money. And though the first half or so of the movie is a little unfocused (though not in a bad way), I like that it pulls it together in the second half to reveal that the usual suspects have all unknowingly robbed Keyser Soze, this legendary figure. It's a fascinating plot, and I was interested in seeing where it was going.

Now here's the twist, maybe the thing the movie is most known for: Verbal Kint was 'Keyser Soze' the whole time, and that his story is made up. I have a lot of problems with this twist, but the odd thing is, most of them I'm not sure are huge or not. The problem is that there's a lot of ambiguity with the ending as to how much of what came before it is real and how much is entirely fabricated. Let's work through this.

To begin with, I guessed pretty much from the beginning that Verbal was somehow not what he seemed, and when the mystery of Keyser Soze was introduced, I immediately figured it was actually Verbal. To be honest, that's not necessarily a fault with the movie; it's more because I knew there'd be a twist and so I was looking out for it. Besides, now, in 2015, so many plot twists have been recycled that to our twist-obsessed culture, looking back at a movie like this, the twist doesn't seem so novel. But I still kind of think there are a lot of clues in the movie. Kevin Spacey's performance is enjoyably off-kilter, and it's kind of clear that he's hiding something dark inside, especially when he ruthlessly kills Saul, which seems uncharacteristic based on his general wimpiness. And when there's seven minutes left in the movie and the only conclusion is 'Keaton actually did it,' you kind of wonder what else could happen. I mean, Keaton is dead, so there's nowhere else for the story to go, but there's the weird loose end of Verbal. Verbal in general feels slightly incidental in a way that indicates there's probably more to him than it seems. Anyways, the predictability of the twist isn't really a flaw, necessarily, but it explains why my mind wasn't insanely blown by the twist. (Fight Club, on the other hand, still managed to shock the hell out of me watching it long after it came out.)

The main problem with the twist, if it is even a problem, is that like I said, it's ambiguous how much of Verbal's story is true. If his entire story was made up, I'd be pretty pissed, honestly, because it'd make everything seem like a waste (this is kind of Roger Ebert's reasoning in his 1 and a half star review). The thing is, though, it seems like a lot of it is true; Kobiyashi shows up at the end to pick up Verbal, and it seems that the earlier scenes with him really did happen; his name just wasn't 'Kobiyashi.' In that case, if all the story is true and Verbal only fabricated the names and things that could serve him, it's a really solid twist. But it looks like the truth is somewhere in between; for example, you'd think based on the twist that Verbal was the one who killed all the usual suspects, but from Verbal's point of view, he was hiding the whole time. So how would he have killed Hockney? The probable answer, of course, is that he wasn't hiding out there the whole time; that was a lie he presented in his story. He probably was sneaking all around, killing each of them. And that leads to my final point...

Generally, what lowers this from 'loving' status to 'liking' status for me is that murkiness with the twist, but mostly because of one core reason: it feels like I'm being cheated a little when it's revealed that what I saw onscreen didn't actually happen. Is it really worth it to throw out a compelling, fun narrative just for the sake of a mind-bending twist (that isn't, I repeat, very unpredictable)? Of course, the twist doesn't completely throw out that story; most of it WAS true, probably, which is why I still really like this movie. But part of the fun in a suspense/mystery/thriller movie is that you get to look at the evidence onscreen and use it to figure out on your own what the truth might be. Watching Verbal hiding while Hockney was killed, I thought, "Oh, I thought Verbal was going to kill them all! I guess I was wrong about the twist!" I didn't realize that what we were seeing onscreen was literally only Verbal's story for the police, even if a lot of it was true. I was looking for little signs in the story that something was off, because THOSE kinds of foreshadowing are so much more powerful than when the onscreen action is a straight up lie. For example: I return to Verbal's uncharacteristic killing of Saul. That was unexpected, and it's a big clue to show that Verbal is more ruthless than he's letting on. But why would he so openly disclose that he killed Saul to the police? It's almost like the filmmakers wanted to try TWO ways of dropping hints: by giving little visual cues and foreshadowing within the context of Verbal's actual story, and by giving signs that what was happening onscreen wasn't real at all, but a distillation of Verbal's story to the police. As I've made clear, I much preferred the former way of foreshadowing.

All in all, despite my mixed feelings about the twist, I think it still mostly works without undoing much of what came before it besides some of the logic of the boat scene. It was full of witty dialogue, enjoyable characters, and suspense, and I'm glad I decided to really pay attention this time.

There's really two things I can say about this movie.  It's a marvellous distillation of the essence of noir thrillers.  It's very arch, and feels constructed, but the final revelations the movie has in store makes that less of a problem than it might seem.  It's also a rare case of a movie that's almost completely immune to the charge of having plot holes since the same revelation renders it all moot.  That might sound horrible ... I have often been annoyed by movies who's final twists makes you feel like you've wasted your time watching them ... but it's really not in this case.  It's so tightly constructed that the journey is worth it even when the destination leads you to question if any of it was real at all.

The performances are all solid enough. The chemistry between the suspects is great. It's the best work that Stephen Baldwin ever did, Benicio Del Toro improvised most of his bits, and Kevin Spacey won an Oscar for his role. (Also keep your eye out for S.H.I.E.L.D's Agent Coulson and Breaking Bad's Chicken Man.) Overall though, the engrossing story (written by Christpher McQuarrie who won an Oscar for it) being told is the centerpiece of this film. It's all about interrogation and gaming with an unreliable narrator. The main story we see is what's being told to us by Spacey's Verbal Kint, but if you really think about it, none of what he tells us is likely to be even 50% true. We are drawn in, and because it's what we're shown we accept it. Keyser Söze's omnipotent ghost  will murder your whole family, and makes murders cower in the boots. Or is he just a fairy tale? The plot twists and turns and hits us with an ending that makes the entire journey questionable and ultimately very satisfying.

Cinema at its best! Spacey was flawless.

The Usual Suspects is pretty much as close to perfect as you can get, in my books. Every actor pulls their weight, every line of the script melts in your mouth, every frame is planned to perfection and every note from those glorious strings in the amazing score will send shivers up your spine. 

We begin with a deliciously noir opening scene, bad guys, good guys and a mound of misbegotten mish-mash which apparently has some significance. We then backtrack with Kevin Spacey recounting some sort of criminal escapade and questions begin to become apparent. Who were these men whose actions resulted in the death of a boatful of men? Why were they on the boat in the first place? And above all, who is Keyser Soze? 

Bryan Singer's direction of this brilliant film is something to be admired. Each scene is effortlessly watchable, without sacrificing the character development for an abundance of entertainment. He creates a murky, yet slightly stylized, underworld for his characters and the atmosphere it creates in the film is an intricate blend of deities and scum, where no-one is what they seem and everyone is hiding something. 

The actors all pull their weight remarkably. Kevin Spacey, in particular, is amazing as Verbal Kint, 'the man with a plan' and awkward limp to go with it. He effortlessly crosses between motor mouth and his softer moments, displaying a great range in his acting and earning himself an Oscar in the process. Every scene of his is believeable and he easily shines brighter than the rest of the considerable cast. 

Gabriel Byrne is great as Dean Keaton, too, showing the raging madman within him as well as the softer points of a man who everytime he gets out, they pull him back in. His moments with Edie are few and far between, so we don't get to see as much of his range as we could have, but his romance is mostly sidelined in this film. 

Benicio Del Toro and Stephen Baldwin are great as Finster and McManus (respectively); the unintelligible man and his hyperactive friend, they are a great addition to the cast and extremely likeable. Chazz Palminteri as Agent Dave Kujan is fantastic as well, though the fact that he's acting opposite Spacey most of the time means that he's often overshadowed by Spacey's brilliance, but his delivery of great lines (you get no immunity from me!) means that he holds his own. Kevin Pollack does well as Todd Hockney, "the man who really didn't give a s**t about anyone." He plays the wisecracking professional well, even though his character isn't as memorable as the others. 

The script is amazing, giving us some of cinema's greatest phrases and tying together what could have been a very scattered movie. The fact that it can keep such tension sustained for so long is a testament to its brilliance. The dialogue between Agent Kujan and Verbal Kint sparkles with dark humour in its brilliant back and forth. 

The score is one of the major components of this film. It is truly brilliant and influenced the world of music in films hugely. The dark strings, reminscent of Jaws, shows the darkness, the intensity, the hint of playfullnes and the danger of the world our characters live in all at once. Guaranteed to stick in your head and change your world. 

The Usual Suspects, as I said before, is pretty much as close to perfect as you can get in afilm: a thrilling mystery, great characters, fantastic script and sound and fantastic direction, all set in a film noir style. I guess not everybody can have the same opinion on a widely praised film. In my honest opinion, I think this movie is very overrated and I don't think that it deserves a 8.7 on imdb. I will start off with what I liked and what I didn't like that kept this movie from being good in my opinion. Kevin Spacey gave a great performance as Verbal Kint and he was the most interesting character in the whole movie. The twists that the film brings in its final half hour are clever and they brought some intelligence in an otherwise average crime/thriller. The movie had a good score and the cinematography was good as well. Now I start with the movie's flaws. Everything with the story and most of its characters just felt really average and I didn't think there was anything truly special brought to the table. Every actor besides Kevin Spacey I felt never stood out and Stephen Baldwin, Benicio Del Toro, Gabriel Byrne, and Kevin Pollak never brought anything to their characters and they ended up being forgettable in my opinion. The mystery going on wasn't very interesting and the movie didn't do anything to truly hook me in. The pacing got slow at times and I felt the movie was trying to explain too much in so little time. I didn't feel anything for the characters and when push came to shove for them, I just said " Oh well." Bryan Singer made mutants interesting in the X-Men franchise, I don't know why he couldn't do that for me with the characters in this crime/mystery film. Overall, it is not a good feeling to me when I end up feeling differently about a critically acclaimed movie but no matter what, I will always give my honest opinion and I feel that this film has way more credit than it deserves.

The greatest trick Kevin Spacey ever pulled was this completely random plot twist which is revered as one of the greatest in cinematic history. This 1995 thriller-crime-drama film is the movie which many claim got Kevin Spacey to where he is now. To some, this film could only be described by the phrase "cinematic masterpiece." The entire movie is told as a flashback of the past six weeks and because of this, the film has an anonymous and ubiquitous narrator. Roger "Verbal" Kint (Kevin Spacey) is the only witness of a nearby boat explosion. He begins telling the story about how he met a group of his fellow criminals or parters-in-crime: Dean Keaton (Gabriel Byrne), Michael McNanus (Stephen Baldwin), Todd Hockney (Kevin Pollak), and Fred Fenster (Benicio Del Toro) for the first time. The Usual Suspects keeps its audience on the edge of their seats with its Oscar-worthy performances, vivid cinematography, and impressive editing. 
	If casting was an Olympic sport, then the casting director of The Usual Suspects would have most definitely won the gold medal. First of all, Kevin Spacey is undoubtedly one of the greatest talents that Hollywood has seen in the past few decades. His performance in this film is what really sells the entire concept to the viewers. There is a quality to Spacey that mesmerizes the audience into believing his story which turns out to be completely false and improvised by his character. Spacey plays "a dumb cripple" as he so eloquently puts it in the film, and therefore gains sympathy and compassion from the audience. He obtains the viewer's loyalty and trust and abruptly betrays it before delivering the epic quote, "The greatest trick the Devil ever pulled was  convincing the world he didn't exist." His performance in this film allocated him his first Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor. Other notable cast members include Stephen Baldwin and Golden Globe winner Gabriel Byrne as well as Kevin Pollak and Academy Award winner Benicio Del Toro; all of the aforementioned cast members gave genuine and respectable performances as well. The performances were amazing, but would have been for nothing without the spectacular cinematography.
	The cinematography of The Usual Suspects is outstanding in terms of quality. This film is sometimes classified as a neo noir film which is evident in its dark and ominous atmosphere. Neo noir films are generally dark and twisted with 1940s/1950s vibe and The Usual Suspects delivers much more than a dark atmosphere with a mid 20th century crime drama allusion. The contrast with the lighting aspect of creating this film was obviously very important and well done. Without the complex cinematography, this film would not have had the eerie and mysterious tone/mood that it would have needed. 
	The editing of this film is so great that it is easy to forget that this is a movie and not actually happening in real life. Generally, action movies make the editing process difficult, but the editing in this film is expertly and exquisitely done. Cutting together several action sequences is no easy task and editing for a film told in a flashback is probably a very tedious and extensive process. One of the greatest edited sequences in the movie happens towards the end when Agent Kujan (Chazz Palminteri) realizes that Verbal's story is a complete and utter lie. During Kujan's realization, the objects which Verbal used to tell his story are shown with close ups and are edited in with Spacey's voiceover telling the key parts of the story. This is the point in the film where viewers understand that Verbal and Keyser Söze are one in the same. 
	The Usual Suspects is critically acclaimed and still beloved by many despite the fact that it was released almost 20 years ago. Besides Spacey's additional Oscar, the film also won Best Screenplay. Keyser Söze has been recognized as one of the best characters in film history. The Usual Suspects is everything an audience wants in a crime drama film including a killer cast, beautiful cinematography, and expertly executed editing. This film is by every definition a "cult classic."

I digress, I went a little encyclopedia brown, Nancy Drew style and solved this case. The ending was a little easy for me personally to sniff out and dig up. However, it was a brilliantly written script, just the puzzle was a little too easy to piece together. This is not to lessen the impact for the average viewer however. I was still relatively rocked and shocked. I'm aware the plot twist was an iconic 180 degree turn that still has people talking to date. It completely altered the story and changed the entire trajectory of the actual film. The fact that the 2 hours we spent watching this was total F.B.S. almost had me writing strongly-worded letters to these filmmakers. An incredibly gripping, entertaining and unpredictable crime drama, Bryan Singer's "The Usual Suspects" is a classic noir film with a twist.

Following Kevin Spacey and featuring Gabriel Byrne, Stephen Baldwin and Pete Postlethwaite, "The Usual Suspects" follows an unusual alliance of criminals working for a shady underworld figure, and the policemen trying to work out the case, in a unique flashback style that keeps the audience guessing.

"The Usual Suspects" runs second to "The Sixth Sense" for one of those movies you will enjoy watching more the second time. I won't give anything away, but there is not one but two twists you won't see coming. And for that sole purpose is a reason to watch this movie. Also, Kevin Spacey might be another reason.

The joy of being a true movie lover is discovering that one film in a hundred that makes it all worthwhile and reminds you again of why you love the medium. That one truly remarkable, original film amid all of the repetitious junk that you've seen before, and me for, "The Usual Suspects" is one of those rare gems. 

It's a densely plotted, one-of-a-kind thriller full of great actors giving rock solid performances and a wonderfully twisted script that may require at least two viewings to successfully sort through. There were bigger names in the cast at the time this was released, but afterwards, the only person anyone was talking about was Kevin Spacey in this star-making and Oscar winning performance of a lifetime. He's quite simply a revelation in this part, an unforgettable role that Spacey brings to life with his own unique flair.

The other real star here making a name for himself is writer Christopher McQuarrie, hitting a home run his first time at bat with his first big screenplay. This is definitely not a film you can do laundry to, as the twists and turns absolutely demand every bit of your attention. It's difficult at times, but the movie proves itself worthy of the work you are required to put into it, culminating with one of the best reveals in movie history, a final twist you'll never see coming but will make you want to watch the film from the beginning the second after it's over.

Secondary viewings of "The Usual Suspects" don't quite maintain the same joy as the first time you see it, but you'll be grateful to have some of your questions answered the second time around. This is truly a brilliant film.

"FIVE SUSPECTS. ONE LINEUP. NO COINCIDENCE."  

- 'The Usual Suspects' is a 1995 crime-thriller with a pinch of mystery to it by director Bryan Singer (X-men, Trick 'r Treat). I enjoyed the smart film noir storyline that unfolds as a puzzle, due to the flashbacks. The fantastic cast shines in this modern themed whodunit with lots of unexpected twists. Starring Gabriel Byrne (28 Weeks Later), Kevin Spacey (K-PAX), Stephen Baldwin (Born on the Fourth of July), Benicio del Toro (The Wolfman), Kevin Pollak (Hostage), Pete Postlethwaite (Jurassic Park: The Lost World) and Chazz Palminteri (A Bronx Tale). Sit back and try to unravel the mystery surrounding Keyser Söze, but keep in mind: nothing is what it seems... 

During a lineup in the investigation of a truck hijack in New York, five criminals meet. Dean Keaton (Byrne) a corrupt policeman who claims to have given up his criminal activity, Todd Hockey (Pollak) who is a hijacker, thief Michael McManus (Baldwin) and his partner-in-crime Fred Fenster (del Toro), and the limping con artist Verbal Kint (Spacey). While they are in holding, McManus convinces them to join forces in committing a robbery. When all has worked out successfully, the men are approached by a lawyer named Kobayashi (Postlethwaite). He works for the mysterious Keyser Söze, a man surrounded by many myths. It becomes clear that they all stole or did something to Söze in the past. To get even, he wants them to destroy 91 million worth of drugs belonging to his rival, that's arriving on a boat. The mission goes horribly wrong when the boat explodes and 27 people end up dead. Now, it's up to special agent Dave Kujan (Palminteri) to find Keyser Söze.
The most complex movie ever made and my favorite so far, guns, black humor and neo noir style at it's best, this is the Usual Suspects.

*THE OFFICIAL BETTER THAN JUNO SEAL*
*Best film of the Week Award*

I've actually watched this film multiple times, but I rewatched it just to make sure it was good, and look out.  It's good.  The Usual Suspects was my first Bryan Singer film and had been a childhood favorite of mine for a while.  I've loved a lot of great things in this film.  The acting, directing, story, characters, and dialogue were all phenomenal.  The film starts off slowly, giving a rather simple plot at first.  Then, many twists and turns are thrown your way and it's one hell of a ride to watch.  This entire week I've watched 8 other movies: Re-Animator (7/10), Breakfast Club (5/10), Arachnophobia rewatch (8/10), There Will Be Blood rewatch (6/10), and the next couple are not worthy of a mention, due  to their value being extremely low.  However, the Usual Suspects earns the best film of the week award, and it wasn't a close finish.  It blew the other films away.

The Usual Suspects starts off really simple.  After a truck has been hijacked and stolen, the police officers capture 5 very high profile criminals: Fenster (played by Benicio del Toro), McManus (Stephen Baldwin), Verbal Kint (Kevin Spacey), Hockney (Pete P.), and Keaton (played by Gabriel Bryne).  Now, they are all very suspicious as to why they were all put in one lineup because you never put 5 very good criminals in the same lineup.  They soon find out that it is a setup, and are put there for one reason, which I won't specify.  However, they are all there because one man wants them to be there; Keyser Soze.  Keyser Soze is a myth, an urban legend, who is rarely seen.  He brings the group together, so that they can take out a huge stash of coke that a rival, Hungarian gang is selling to the Argentinians.  Of course....there is more to this plot than meets the eye, and when it comes full circle, you'll be amazed.

The best part of the Usual Suspects is the dialogue.  It's snappy, quick, and very witty at times.  The actors speak a mile a minute, so you better be paying close attention to what they say or you'll be forced to rewind the scene to get the dialogue right.  While this may not bode well with many people, this actually gives the film a huge advantage for me.  There is a lot of things to be said in this film and if they spoke at a mild pace, it would really slow the film down.  Also, there are moments of pure wit and hilarity.  When I had to rewind a scene because I missed one important line, I found a couple of funny one-liners tossed in, such as when McManus broke the fourth wall.  It's fun to know that there are some lines you'll miss, so you test yourself to see if you got it.  Many casual moviegoers will be scratching their heads trying to make sense, that is if they have slow hearing.  However, most people shouldn't really have a problem.

Another wonderful thing is the style and acting.  It's a very slickly made film, featuring Singer's typical flare that he adds to all his films.  The camera pans are stylistic and some shots are purely magical.  I love when a film can combine both style and substance into one amazing concoction of epic proportions, and this film is one of those films.  Unlike *cough*Drive*cough*, it has enough narrative smarts and more than 1 line of dialogue per scene.  And unlike Bullhead (fight me, Belgians), it has enough style to keep the film fresh and unique.  However, where the film is nearly at it's best is the acting.  All of the actors gave well rounded performances.  Gabriel Bryne as Keaton is a mix of anger and self loathing.  Benicio Del Toro has great comedic moments in his scenes, though he was more of a background character.  Stephen Baldwin gave a good performance as well.  However, the one man that stole the show....was none other than John Doe: Kevin Spacey.  I've always known Spacey was a great actor, but here, it's like on a different level.  Sure, his John Doe performance in Se7en was great.  One of the best.  However, I completely found myself more interested in Verbal Kint.  A truly unique character, with some great acting, can end up being the best thing ever.

Overall, to keep it short.  The Usual Suspects is one of my favorite films ever.  It's fast paced, fun, and filled to the brim with great dialogue.  The acting is phenomenal from all, especially Kevin Spacey.  The dialogue is spoken a little too fast at times.  And I did predict the ending, though I doubted it a couple of times.  And Benicio del Toro should've had a bigger part in it.  However, those flaws are easily outmatched by this simple, yet cunning film.  Crafted by a good director in Springer, coupled with an excellent script, this is a prime example of what crime dramas should be about.  Have a good amount of substance and tension, while throwing in some style, and you will have yourselves another classic.

It's unfortunate that years before I finally saw this movie last night, even though I've had it on DVD for a while now as well, I already knew who Keyser Soze was.  So, easily, the most important part of the film was spoiled to me.  And I can pretty much guarantee that knowing who Keyser was heavily affected the score I ended up giving the movie.  Don't get me wrong, I still think the movie is absolutely incredible, but going in blind is definitely the best way to go if you want the reveal to have the most impact possible.  Having said that, knowing what happened, opened my eyes into viewing the film in a completely different manner.  Because of that, I focused on the way the film reaches the conclusion of who Keyser Soze really is and what his plan was, rather than on the fact that I already knew who it was.  And I must say that the way the film gets to its climax is absolutely masterful.  A tip of the hat to the screenwriter, Christopher McQuarrie, the editors and Bryan Singer for crafting such an intriguing and compelling film.  This is a film that starts off with a very simple concept, 5 criminals come together to pull a series of heists, they're contacted by Keyser Soze's lawyer, Mr. Kobayashi, as all 5 of the criminals have, unknowingly, stolen from Mr. Soze.  Keyser provides the 5 men with a chance to repay their debt if they do one last job for him.  This is where the movie really gets going, because there's film throws on so many layers of betrayal and deceit that you know that you pretty much can't trust anybody in this film.  The film, since it's handled so expertly, isn't that hard to follow at all considering how much is actually going on story-wise.  There's so much information that the film wants to get out that it's very surprising, in a good way, to see that the film doesn't become confusing or hard to follow.  That's also a credit to the editing of the film.  Of course the biggest, and most important, part of the film centers around the mystery of who is Keyser Soze.  I'll try my hardest not to spoil the film, as that'll take out some of the fun out of it, but the handling of this character was absolute genius.  It's really hard to distinguish what's real and what's fake about Keyser.  Perhaps he wasn't even as bad as some people believed he was, it's just that the the stories involving him kept getting more and more exaggerated.  It seems, to me, that his reputation preceded him.  Maybe he even spread these lies around in order to make sure that no one fucked with him.  I believe there's a hint of truth to Keyser's backstory.  Not all of it, but some of it.  Everything else was spread around in order to create fear among his enemies.  Of course, that's all a theory in my mind.  Because if it was true, why would the Hungarians and the Argentinians have that deal that the 5 criminals were sent to break up.  And the way that Keyser manipulates every little thing, no matter how small, and person in order to get what he wants was, again, a stroke of genius.  Everything goes pretty much exactly as Keyser intended and it's an absolutely joy to watch.  That's part of the reason I enjoyed the film so much.  The fact that I knew who Keyser Soze was, it led me to pay attentions to the smaller details and seeing how everybody was pretty much manipulated by this man.  It'd be embarrassing if it was real.  The acting is strong, and Kevin Spacey absolutely kills it here.  I think that's about all I'm going to say on the acting because it, again, might spoil the film for some and I don't want that.  Even if the film is almost 20 years old, I don't want to anybody who might be seeing it for the first time.  With that said, I absolutely this movie for completely different reasons than I would've had it not been spoiled for me.  It's still an incredible film.  Don't be fooled by the fact that it starts off like a simple heist film.  Trust me when I say it's anything but a typical heist film.  There's twists and turns that'd make M. Night Shyamalan shit in his pants.
It's still very good and very well made, but it really felt like a rehash of Reservoir Dogs to and extent, minus Tarantino's great dialogue, up until the end of the second act.

The Usual Suspects was an odd surprise for me to see in some people's top 10 lists or be regarded as one of the best crime films in the 90s as I personally felt that this was a let down.

The film was written by Christopher McQuarrie, who as of now has a small filmography and is usually in collaboration with director, Bryan Singer. What McQuarrie has written here is a crime drama that also takes in some elements of the supernatural, but it is only used as a symbol or metaphor of sorts rather than an actual supernatural being. I personally did not like the first half of the film, as it just threw us in with these characters and never gives an opportunity to introduce us to them. I ended up not caring about the problems that they were facing because I never had this sort of connection or at the very least an understanding of their existence in this story. We only really see the inner layers of two characters throughout the entire film and it kind of ruins the suspense and mystery, as it makes it easier for us to predict who the suspect is. I don't care if the film's running time extends for an extra 30 minutes, all five characters should be evenly fleshed out (or at least close to it). Another problem that I had with McQuarrie's writing is the dialogue. A lot of the times, it feels so campy and been overly used in many similar films before it. McQuarrie wasn't able to create a higher variety of personalities for his characters, that they all feel the same. The only character that he gave great dialogue to was to Roger Kint (Kevin Spacey). It seems that he was too preoccupied with writing great characters like Dean Keaton and Roger Kint, that he forgot to make the others just as equally interesting. I also found the fable of Keyser Soze to be a bit underwhelming, as I expected more from such a legendary figure. Maybe if the tale also related itself to the crime world that these characters are in, then that way I could at least see the connection right from the start on how his reputation in the crime world was so established. What I did like about his screenplay was the latter part of the film, starting at the introduction of Kobayashi, as this is the point where our characters are in real danger and it got me curious on how they can get out of this situation. This is where the mystery starts to begin, as this is where everything builds up to the climax of the film. The first half never really contributed that much to the film's payoff. The film's climax is the main reason why I come back to see this film, as it's so well written. It contains twists that I didn't see coming and it allowed me to be more appreciative of the performances of some actors during subsequent viewings. Though the ending doesn't give you a full conclusion or truth on the incident, instead it gives you something much more, an interesting story filled with half truths or in other terms, gossip. How do things spread, it's due to gossip or word of mouth and through this, hype is built. Sometimes the truth is so underwhelming and that it was better before when it was just full of crap. I think McQuarrie knew this, which is why he never gave a hint of a real conclusion for any of these characters.

The film was directed by Bryan Singer and this would be his second feature film. Singer understood that the film would be at it's most effective if it creates it as a mystery with a surprise at the end rather than have an orthodox crime film. Through this approach, Singer has definitely made something that stood out above the rest, regardless of how I feel about the film as a whole. He makes the most out of McQuarrie's screenplay and tried to build us much tension of it as he could, thought at some cases he fails. This failure is more due to the lack of depth in the script, but when the script gets going, Singer shows what he could do. Singer is more of a mainstream director and he isn't at all pretentious with his work, so the film overall is just a take it or leave it experience. I feel that this approach will truly work if you bring something unique to the experience, examples of this include Reservoir Dogs and Memento; unique yet accessible. Due to the half of the film is disappointing in the writing department, it felt quite slow. It desperately needed something to jump start me in order to keep myself engaged, which did arrive but not until halfway through. Singer does start it off with a murder that did made me curious, but that scene doesn't become relevant until much later.

The film's director of cinematography was Newton Thomas Sigel, who is also known to collaborate with Singer. Sigel doesn't really bring anything interesting here, as there really isn't much room to bring any sense of depth and/or style. He just shoots what he needs in order for the audience to keep up with the narrative. The shots that Singer and Sigel have chosen usually consists of these slow zooms and tracking shots to kind of give us an idea that we are getting closer and closer to something big. As the action set pieces don't sell the film as such, there was a huge emphasis on facial shots and have Singer cut to each character in order to give us their reaction to a situation, and it does kind of give more to these characters than what is actually written for them. The construction of the shots during the climax and the way Singer and his editor assemble it, is the main core of what makes the audience feel surprised. I commend Singer for this, as if this failed then the entire film would have been a disaster and it's effect on the audience wouldn't be thought of so highly today.

John Ottman is the film's composer and his work here was really a let down. I can definitely see that it is a great score but it feels out of place for a film like this, as it never created any effect of suspense or tension for me. It just felt like it was there for the sake of being there. Take another crime film from that period, Se7en. That film's score was so well crafted in creating this dark and gritty mood. The Usual Suspects doesn't have to go that route, as it is a much more lighter film, but it could have been the same in the way the score was able to get reactions from us and creating tension.

The film has a decent line up of actors playing the 5 main characters, though some did kind of disappoint me as they reached to a point of annoyance. Gabriel Byrne as Dean Keaton was actually great to watch. Byrne character was quite focused on the film, so Byrne had a lot to work with. In this film, Byrne was able to give depth that the character needed in order to for his character to be sympathised. There always seems to be something behind his face, as if there is something that he isn't showing us. Keaton is the only one where we see a bit of his backstory and relationships. Stephen Baldwin as McManus was decent, though there wasn't really a lot for him to do. Baldwin plays him as a hothead who doesn't hates being antagonised. At times he does bring energy to the scene, but it is only brief. Kevin Pollak plays as Hockney, who for the most part is dull. This is due to both the writing and the acting. There is just nothing to this character except for a couple of lines and an extra person for the boat scene near the end. Chazz Palminetri as Dave Kujan, the officer/detective that interrogates Kevin Spacey, was good for the most part. He does bring this intensity and attitude to the role, which suits him and the character he is playing. When he delivers his lines, it shows how immersed he is with the role. The main issue with him though is the lines that he has to say, it's not in his execution but in the writing. There are moments where he just comes off as stereotypical and it does kind of draws a bit of attention to itself. Benicio Del Toro was irritating to watch. I have seen him in better performances and what he brings here is just over the top and weird. Why does he need that almost non-understandable accent? Sometimes less is more. Kevin Spacey was quite mesmerizing as Roger Kint, as he was convincing as the character all the way through; he did come off as a vulnerable man, which was important in order to sell the character. I can't say this was his best role, as personally I thought of him more highly in American Beauty and Se7en.

The Usual Suspects is regarded to be a cult classic.And I must say that I admire this movie.It had me hooked to it,leaving aside the fact that I was awfully confused quite a few times throughout the movie-and there are multiple reasons for it too.Firstly,there are so many characters in this movie,that it does get a little confusing to follow.The narrative style of the movie is also a little confusing at times.
 The most impressive thing about the movie is probably Kevin Spacey as Verbal Kint,who is a crippled con man.He plays his role with a perfection that must be seen to be believed.The other actors do have their own charm,but Spacey steals the show in almost every scene he is in.

 The movie is complex and is really difficult to follow at times.The direction,and the skilled performances help in keeping our attention at its best.The Usual Suspects definitely has something going for it,and I can understand why it is a cult classic.Its only the confusion and some really bothering questions arising after watching the movie that make it not-so-perfect,but a really well done movie for me.

El agente de servicio de aduanas le dice a nuestro "sospechoso habitual" protagonista: "Convénzame". Y eso trata de hacer este filme al espectador. El susodicho protagonista narra, mostrado mediante flashbacks, la causa, con todo detalle, de un incendio de un barco que provocó 27 víctimas, empezando por el arresto de cinco "sospechosos habituales", causa de un robo de un camión de armas. A medida que avanza la trama, ambos sucesos se enlazan cronológicamente, desde la unión de los cinco para solucionar sus problemas hasta el incendio, todo ello contado hasta el más mínimo detalle.

En cuanto al entretenimiento, el montaje y las muy notables actuaciones son los puntos clave para que las dos horas de metraje se te pasen volando mientras atiendes. Pasando a la historia, al susodicho protagonista no se le escapa ni un detalle de lo sucedido, resultando ser tan convincente como el agente pide. A raíz de esto, a medida que va avanzando la película se van produciendo enigmas, llegando a una resolución definitiva que no dejará indiferente, en el que todos los cabos, ya coherentemente atados de por sí, vuelven a hacerlo agarrando más firmeza... Y todo esto gracias a un guión milimétrico acompañado del excepcional montaje.

Los posibles (y muy probablemente existentes) errores del filme son nimiedades que no afectan al nudo del filme (¡atención!), y aunque se deba reconocer su imperfección, hay que recordar que no todo es perfecto y que hay que aclamar un trabajo bien hecho. Brillante y altamente recomendada, y, después de 'Se7en', el mejor thriller de su año.

It's a complicated movie from the start and you really don't know exactly what's going on from the very beginning. The directing is very good, but the story is told in a pretty confusing way. The plot itself starts out pretty simple and then piles of backstories and characters and drama is added to the foundation. It's a very well made, engaging, exciting film, with great acting, especially by Kevin Spacey, very well fleshed out characters, and a tremendously innovative and creative plot. As for that famous plot twist at the end, you're really left guessing when it will come and what it is, as there are so many plot twists in this film, many of them quite large. However, at the end, be prepared for the world created in this film to be turned completely upside down.

I don't think "The Usual Suspects" is a particularly bad movie, but I don't think it is a great one either. This movie is quite literally so obvious that it's impossible not to see the twist coming.  Who else could honestly be the antagonist?  The setup gets 4-and-a-half stars, but this is the first movie I've ever reviewed for a reason:  I was furious after watching, because I expected to be surprised by the twist that I was sure had to be coming, but extremely disappointed by how obvious the "twist" was.  Perhaps it's my fault for going into the movie with the expectation that I would be surprised by what everybody says is a twist worthy of what IMDB calls the twenty-sixth best movie of all time.  Perhaps it's my fault for believing that so many critics declaring the so-called twist "satisfying" and "surprising" (via Rotten Tomatoes) had to be true, or for believing that 95% of RT users deeming the film "fresh" in addition to the 88% of critics giving the same rating had to mean something, but the final reveal is so obvious that it renders the skill and thought with which the previous 100-and-some-odd minutes are portrayed absolutely moot.  
     I wanted this to be a good movie.  I wanted this to be a great movie.  But in the end, what I want most is an apology.  I am personally offended by this film.  Offended that someone as dim-witted as myself could see the plot "twist" coming from the very first minute of the movie.  Offended that the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences could give two Oscars to a film so unremarkable when there are so many deserving movies out there.  Offended at how universally lauded this film is.  But most of all, I'm offended that Bryan Singer, Christopher McQuarrie, the entire cast, crew, and anyone involved in the production of this picture at Bad Hat Harry, Blue Parrot, Spelling, Gramercy, PolyGram, or Universal could ever think of their audience as so pathetically stupid that we would never see coming that the main antagonist is the person we should least suspect.
