Bryan Singer brings perfect direction to a film that focuses on five criminals who are arrested after a heist and put through a lineup. The five unlikely criminals are than forced to work together after being contacted by a lawyer who works for Keyser Soze, who wants them to rob a boat of cocaine. Many of the actors in the film are wonderful, primarily Gabriel Byrne, Kevin Spacey and Chas Palminteri. The whole film is recounted through flashbacks while Spacey's character, a handicapped criminal gives information to Palminteri's detective about the events that lead up to the incident surrounding the boat. John Ottman's score is brilliant and Christopher McQuarrie's screenplay is wonderful and surprising, delivering several unexpected twists. The best part of the film is the ending, which will probably be talked about over and over again after people have seen the film. Absolutely brilliant.

The Usual Suspects is certainly an unusual movie at times. It may take a while to understand just what the hell is going on for the first 30 minutes or so, but once you understand the underlying plot and the main characters, the intrigue definitely engrosses you into the mystery. Singer did a solid job of reinventing the wheel--the film's  play out wasn't unique, but it's execution certainly had style. This film will leave you thinking and even laughing up till the very end when you have that "ah ha" moment and realize everything that has happened.

The title comes from a line in "Casablanca" through an article in "Spy" magazine. A highly stylized, intricate thriller from writer Christopher McQuarrie and director Brian Singer, this is the most entertaining convoluted mystery since "The Big Sleep." It begins with a gang of criminals gathered together for a police lineup that leads to a failed drug heist on a Los Angeles harbor. In the aftermath, a customs detective (Chazz Palminteri) interrogates a lone survivor, a verbose cripple (Kevin Spacey), who recounts, in flashbacks and narration, the events that led to the heist organized by the mysterious Hungarian criminal mastermind, Keyser Soze. (The identification of Soze is the most brilliantly executed revelation since Orson Welles appeared as Harry Lime in "The Third Man.") But how much of what we see actually happened? The brilliantly assembled cast is fantastic. Won Oscars for Best Supporting Actor (Kevin Spacey) and Best Original Screenplay (Christopher McQuarrie.) Cinematography by Newton Thomas Sigel; John Ottman was the editor and composed the simple pulsating music score. With Gabriel Byrne, Stephen Baldwin, Kevin Pollak, Benicio del Toro, Pete Postlethwaite, Suzy Amis, Giancarlo Esposito, Dan Hedaya, and Peter Greene.
Some of it makes no sense, but the film has a great script and Kevin Spacey delivers his best performance in years.

In 1995 a little film called The Usual Suspects came out, over the course of it's release in theaters it did not do that well barley making over a million dollars in the US. However the film did win two Academy Awards, Best Supporting Actor (Kevin Spacey) and Best Original Screenplay (Christopher McQuarrie). Since it's release in 1995 many people fell in love with The Usual Suspects, including myself. I recently saw The Usual Suspects for the first time and I must say that I was blown away by this film, I think this movie is truly brilliant and in a genre of it's own making it a very unique film. Everything in this film was just amazing, especially the script that was written by Christopher McQuarrie. McQuarrie deserved the win at the Oscars because his writing for this film was just incredible. One thing he did that blew me away is the fact that he put so many different genres into one film; I mean there's comedy, action, drama, mystery, and a little bit of a thriller all in one movie and it works perfectly. The story for this film was just fabulous and they way it was told was amazing. This film has one big twist that I thought worked perfectly, personally I sort of saw it coming but when it was revealed I was still shocked if that makes any sense. One thing I love about this movie is that there is not one dull moment to me, I was entertained the whole entire run time. I can't talk about The Usual Suspects without mentioning the dialogue, the dialogue is just astonishing and it's so good that it doesn't even feel like your watching a movie. I also loved how witty the dialogue was, every joke in this movie hit the right note for me. Bryan Singer directed this movie and this is the film that put him on the map because he did such a fascinating job directing this film. I thought his style was perfect for the film and that his vision for everything was magnificent. He also did such an incredible job at directing this huge group of talented actors and managed to get them all to give the best performances they possible could; that brings me to the acting. The acting in this film was just wonderful, each character was magnificently written and had enough background for you to care about them and each actor portrayed there character perfectly. Every actor gives a knockout performance in this movie and that includes Gabriel Byrne, Kevin Spacey, Stephen Baldwin, Benicio Del Toro, Kevin Pollak, and many others, there are just so many people in this movie to name. Another thing worth mentioning is the John Ottoman's excellent score which fit the film perfectly. In the end The Usual Suspects became on of my favorites and is a film that I encourage you to see.

The Usual Suspects was an odd surprise for me to see in some people's top 10 lists or be regarded as one of the best crime films in the 90s as I personally felt that this was a let down.

The film was written by Christopher McQuarrie, who as of now has a small filmography and is usually in collaboration with director, Bryan Singer. What McQuarrie has written here is a crime drama that also takes in some elements of the supernatural, but it is only used as a symbol or metaphor of sorts rather than an actual supernatural being. I personally did not like the first half of the film, as it just threw us in with these characters and never gives an opportunity to introduce us to them. I ended up not caring about the problems that they were facing because I never had this sort of connection or at the very least an understanding of their existence in this story. We only really see the inner layers of two characters throughout the entire film and it kind of ruins the suspense and mystery, as it makes it easier for us to predict who the suspect is. I don't care if the film's running time extends for an extra 30 minutes, all five characters should be evenly fleshed out (or at least close to it). Another problem that I had with McQuarrie's writing is the dialogue. A lot of the times, it feels so campy and been overly used in many similar films before it. McQuarrie wasn't able to create a higher variety of personalities for his characters, that they all feel the same. The only character that he gave great dialogue to was to Roger Kint (Kevin Spacey). It seems that he was too preoccupied with writing great characters like Dean Keaton and Roger Kint, that he forgot to make the others just as equally interesting. I also found the fable of Keyser Soze to be a bit underwhelming, as I expected more from such a legendary figure. Maybe if the tale also related itself to the crime world that these characters are in, then that way I could at least see the connection right from the start on how his reputation in the crime world was so established. What I did like about his screenplay was the latter part of the film, starting at the introduction of Kobayashi, as this is the point where our characters are in real danger and it got me curious on how they can get out of this situation. This is where the mystery starts to begin, as this is where everything builds up to the climax of the film. The first half never really contributed that much to the film's payoff. The film's climax is the main reason why I come back to see this film, as it's so well written. It contains twists that I didn't see coming and it allowed me to be more appreciative of the performances of some actors during subsequent viewings. Though the ending doesn't give you a full conclusion or truth on the incident, instead it gives you something much more, an interesting story filled with half truths or in other terms, gossip. How do things spread, it's due to gossip or word of mouth and through this, hype is built. Sometimes the truth is so underwhelming and that it was better before when it was just full of crap. I think McQuarrie knew this, which is why he never gave a hint of a real conclusion for any of these characters.

The film was directed by Bryan Singer and this would be his second feature film. Singer understood that the film would be at it's most effective if it creates it as a mystery with a surprise at the end rather than have an orthodox crime film. Through this approach, Singer has definitely made something that stood out above the rest, regardless of how I feel about the film as a whole. He makes the most out of McQuarrie's screenplay and tried to build us much tension of it as he could, thought at some cases he fails. This failure is more due to the lack of depth in the script, but when the script gets going, Singer shows what he could do. Singer is more of a mainstream director and he isn't at all pretentious with his work, so the film overall is just a take it or leave it experience. I feel that this approach will truly work if you bring something unique to the experience, examples of this include Reservoir Dogs and Memento; unique yet accessible. Due to the half of the film is disappointing in the writing department, it felt quite slow. It desperately needed something to jump start me in order to keep myself engaged, which did arrive but not until halfway through. Singer does start it off with a murder that did made me curious, but that scene doesn't become relevant until much later.

The film's director of cinematography was Newton Thomas Sigel, who is also known to collaborate with Singer. Sigel doesn't really bring anything interesting here, as there really isn't much room to bring any sense of depth and/or style. He just shoots what he needs in order for the audience to keep up with the narrative. The shots that Singer and Sigel have chosen usually consists of these slow zooms and tracking shots to kind of give us an idea that we are getting closer and closer to something big. As the action set pieces don't sell the film as such, there was a huge emphasis on facial shots and have Singer cut to each character in order to give us their reaction to a situation, and it does kind of give more to these characters than what is actually written for them. The construction of the shots during the climax and the way Singer and his editor assemble it, is the main core of what makes the audience feel surprised. I commend Singer for this, as if this failed then the entire film would have been a disaster and it's effect on the audience wouldn't be thought of so highly today.

John Ottman is the film's composer and his work here was really a let down. I can definitely see that it is a great score but it feels out of place for a film like this, as it never created any effect of suspense or tension for me. It just felt like it was there for the sake of being there. Take another crime film from that period, Se7en. That film's score was so well crafted in creating this dark and gritty mood. The Usual Suspects doesn't have to go that route, as it is a much more lighter film, but it could have been the same in the way the score was able to get reactions from us and creating tension.

The film has a decent line up of actors playing the 5 main characters, though some did kind of disappoint me as they reached to a point of annoyance. Gabriel Byrne as Dean Keaton was actually great to watch. Byrne character was quite focused on the film, so Byrne had a lot to work with. In this film, Byrne was able to give depth that the character needed in order to for his character to be sympathised. There always seems to be something behind his face, as if there is something that he isn't showing us. Keaton is the only one where we see a bit of his backstory and relationships. Stephen Baldwin as McManus was decent, though there wasn't really a lot for him to do. Baldwin plays him as a hothead who doesn't hates being antagonised. At times he does bring energy to the scene, but it is only brief. Kevin Pollak plays as Hockney, who for the most part is dull. This is due to both the writing and the acting. There is just nothing to this character except for a couple of lines and an extra person for the boat scene near the end. Chazz Palminetri as Dave Kujan, the officer/detective that interrogates Kevin Spacey, was good for the most part. He does bring this intensity and attitude to the role, which suits him and the character he is playing. When he delivers his lines, it shows how immersed he is with the role. The main issue with him though is the lines that he has to say, it's not in his execution but in the writing. There are moments where he just comes off as stereotypical and it does kind of draws a bit of attention to itself. Benicio Del Toro was irritating to watch. I have seen him in better performances and what he brings here is just over the top and weird. Why does he need that almost non-understandable accent? Sometimes less is more. Kevin Spacey was quite mesmerizing as Roger Kint, as he was convincing as the character all the way through; he did come off as a vulnerable man, which was important in order to sell the character. I can't say this was his best role, as personally I thought of him more highly in American Beauty and Se7en.

However, the lines the characters feed us are a little too slick, and some of the acting is a bit over done, especially on the part of Chazz Palminteri and Stephen Baldwin. Benicio Del Toro is unfortunately not at his best, while Kevin Spacey presents the top performance of the lot, and the rest of the cast gives only an acceptable one, but not much better.

If you like criminal intrigue, you probably will like it.

A relatively simple thriller it seemed in the beginning but was shot into the league of the greatest suspense films just by a single masterstroke in the end, which also changed the entire perspective of the viewer & throws away whatever information he/she had acquired over the runtime, & that's where this film's biggest strength lies. Direction by Bryan Singer is superb as he really made the tension build up superbly & added layers after layers of twists, thus confusing its viewers & finally plays a masterstroke that changes everything. Performances are really good from all & remarkable one from Kevin Spacey. Overall, The Usual Suspects is tense, tightly structured, captivating, twisting & confusing but the unforgettable ending will solve it all for you, after you've recovered from the final shock.

What seems like a typical 90's crime thriller is a lot more interesting and fun than most would think. The Usual Suspects strings together a group of interesting characters in an interluded storyline that is fascinating and unexpected. Even though my initial estimation was correct, it was not without a series of doubt, surprise and ultimately conviction to find out about the unexpected. Visually, the film is also extremely stylish. The combination of a solid story with interesting, rememberable characters guarantees The Usual Suspects a place in film history and worthy of repeated viewings. Just as the film title suggest, the group of characters would be considered the "usual" in most circumstances, but in this case they are anything but "usual", just like the film itself, The Usual Suspects is anything but a usual crime thriller.

Bryan Singer's whodunit maintains its mystique even after almost two decades. The turns and twists of the plot remain thrilling even when the ending is known. Spacey's performance and McQuarrie's script remain the two stand-out parts of the movie, though the remainder of the performances are still impressive. The Usual Suspects is still one of the textbook examples of the crime whodunit, and it is a must-see for fans of American cinema and pop culture.

A movie that strives to be more than it is, and succeeds greatly in doing so.
This movie was great and left me wanting more... the characters were very well developed.

Although the film is perhaps a little slow in fully developing, the consequent results are astounding. Spacey's performance is captivating and will only be fully appreciated once the viewing is complete. The supporting cast, including Gabriel Byrne, provide the basis for a convincing drama which will change the way you perceive crime thrillers in the future.

One is required to discover the identity of the elusive Keyser Soze throughout the film and if it were not for the well thought-out script and professional dramatic acting then the viewer would feel a sense of anti-climax. However, this is not the case; you shall be left speechless and wondering how the film achieved its goal.

Aún cuando la carrera de director de Bryan Singer ha tenido altibajos, no se puede negar que "The Usual Suspects" es su mejor película que figura como #26 del Top250 de IMDB. Este es de esos filmes que entre menos sepan sobre la trama antes de verla, mejor. Ya que si alguien les dice ciertos elementos clave del guión, simplemente su experiencia con el filme será arruinada. Es evidente que la influencia de "Reservoir Dogs" está presente, y con un mayor presupuesto a la mano para poder desarrollar escenas más ambiciosas. Igualmente es sorprendente el trabajo de John Ottman en la composición musical, ya que es realmente buena, a diferencia de sus subsecuentes trabajos que no fueron tan memorables u originales. El filme tiene un elenco impresionante en donde todos encarnan a la perfección sus personajes y en donde muchos de ellos lograron las mejores actuaciones de sus carreras. Además de que el filme cuenta con una de las líneas más memorables de la historia reciente del cine... "El más grande truco que El Diablo ha logrado es convencer al mundo que él no existe." Uff! Altamente recomendada.

This is the first film I've watched in 2013, and I must say it's a hell of a start. My hype for this was positively met. It's an amazing designed crime thriller, comparable in quality to another movie Spacey stars in, released the same year,Se7en. After the first twenty minutes it was never easy to follow, this made it all the more intriguing. Like the large majority of people I strongly preferred the second half. Most notably the concluding ten minutes, which messed with your heart and mind. I only fully grasped the final twist the following morning. It was grade A quality. Spacey best performance by far, he deserved his Oscar. The story was pure genius, and while it dragged in some parts, I really can't say I was ever bored.

A modern classic that I've seen more time than I care to remember. Although the thing that made it famous and beloved is the surprise twist at the end (one that you'll guaranteed to never forget), everything building up to it is a delight to watch. The five thieving and scheming protagonists are all colorful and lively; the dialogue is sharp and even hilarious at times; and the writing is intelligent. Even the soundtrack and editing deserve special mentioning for their ability to stand out from the forgettable fare we usually hear and see. If for nothing else, watch it for Kevin Spacey's performance.

A movie whose name is gotten from a line in the old classic, Casablanca âThe Usual Suspectâ is about an interrogation gone wrong. The movie is very hard to connect together, and the masterful twist ending for some did more harm than good, but for me it was the thriller of the whole movie. The fact that after the movie is over I still have to sit down and think about it, connecting the dots and wanting to have another re-run of the movie to be sure that I donâ(TM)t miss any dot, that is the reason why this movie is a master piece.

Written by Christopher McQuarrie, the Keyser SÃ¶ze character is based on the accounts of John List, an accountant who murdered his family in 1971 and then disappeared for almost 20 years by assuming a new identity before he was eventually apprehended in 1989. McQuarrie got the name Keyser SÃ¶ze from the name of his former supervisor Keyser Sume, and the last name SÃ¶ze is Turkish which is translated as "talk too much."

The Interrogation scene was first shot and it ran for 6 days, and the rest of the movie was put together next and editing was the grand touch that made this mystery thriller that good a movie to see.

The movie plot is about the interrogation of a small time con man named Roger "Verbal" Kint (Kevin Spacey), who is a one of the only two survivors of a heist gone wrong that resulted to a fire on a ship. He tells the interrogator the series of events that led him and four other criminals to the boat.

This series of events are shown to the viewer in the form of flashbacks as Kint narrates his story to the over confident interrogator. As the story goes on and gets complex the interrogator connects the dots and explains the story better to Kint, only to get the shocker of his life when he releases Kint believing he was used by the other four.

Done with a 6 million dollar production budget, the movie recouped its production cost and more; the well crafted screenplay by Christopher McQuarrie gained him an Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay and Kevin Spacey won the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor for his performance as the criminal Keyser SÃ¶ze.

The Usual suspect is a fine film, well developed to push the imaginations of the viewer, the unexpected ending is the cream on the top of this delicious masterpiece and one thing is sure, you will be asking for seconds after you are done seeing it the first time.
